title: China's Exports Extend Their Decline in September
text:
BEIJING--China's exports contracted further in September, hurt by the prolonged trade dispute between the China and the U.S. amid slowing global economic growth.

China's exports last month decreased 3.2% from a year earlier, following August's 1.0% drop, data from the General Administration of Customs showed Monday. A Wall Street Journal poll of economists had tipped a 3.0% decline.

Imports slid 8.5% on year in September, extending August's 5.6% drop, the customs data showed. The WSJ poll had forecast a decline of 6.0%.

China's overall trade surplus stood at $39.65 billion in September, wider than August's $34.8 billion surplus and the $34.05 billion surplus that had been expected.

Trade tensions between China and the U.S. have eased a little following last week's high-level trade talks, with the U.S. shelving new tariffs against Beijing while leaving many demands to be worked out later, in return for an assurance of increased agriculture purchases by China.

--Lin Zhu

(END) Dow Jones Newswires
